channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sadiq Khan, London’s Muslim Mayor, Calls Trump ‘Ignorant About Islam’
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, at City Hall on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The new mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, asserted that Mr. Trump was playing into the hands of extremists.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Italy Approves Same-Sex Civil Unions
item.description: The law, opposed by the Vatican, stops short of gay marriage but brings Italy more in line with other Western European countries.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Germany Says It Will Rescind Convictions for Homosexuality
item.media:description: Mourners laid a wreath in Berlin in January in memory of the homosexual victims of the Nazis during the Holocaust.
item.description: From 1949 to 1969, under a law inherited from the Nazi regime, some 50,000 men were convicted of homosexuality, and many served prison terms.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Lack of Plan for ISIS Detainees Raises Human Rights Concerns
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces detained men suspected of being members of the Islamic State for interrogation last month. The men were found among civilians returning to Ramadi.
item.description: The United States, determined not to get back into detention operations, has no strategy in place for handling potentially thousands of war prisoners.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: She Won a Seat in Iran’s Parliament, but Hard-Liners Had Other Plans
item.media:description: Minoo Khaleghi, a reformist politician, had won a seat in the Iranian Parliament in February.
item.description: Minoo Khaleghi easily won a seat in February’s election but was disqualified over claims she did not wear a head scarf on visits to Europe and China.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Braces for Brazilian Senate’s Impeachment Vote
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil walking in the gardens around the Palácio da Alvorada, the presidential residence, in Brasília on Wednesday.
item.description: Aides to Ms. Rousseff described the atmosphere in the halls of her palaces as a mixture of grim resignation with a dash of gallows humor.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Brazil’s Senate Begins Debate on Ousting Dilma Rousseff After Months of Turmoil
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil during the opening ceremony of the National Policy Conference for Women in Brasilia on Tuesday.
item.description: The debate, followed by a vote as early as Wednesday evening, is a watershed in the power struggle consuming the country.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Obama’s Visit Raises Ghosts of Hiroshima
item.media:description: A mushroom cloud billowed about an hour after the nuclear bomb was detonated on Aug. 6, 1945, over Hiroshima, Japan.
item.media:credit: U.S. Army, via Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum, via Associated Press
item.description: Most people in Japan believe the city was a victim of unnecessary brutality, but for Americans of the World War II generation, Hiroshima is at the center of a very different narrative.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Poised to Lead Philippines, Is Expected to Take New Approach to China
item.media:description: Supporters of Rodrigo Duterte during an election campaign rally in Manila on Saturday. Ballots were still being tabulated on Wednesday, but Mr. Duterte was far ahead of his nearest rival.
item.description: Mr. Duterte — who was far ahead of his rivals in presidential election returns — will put development opportunities ahead of defense issues, analysts predict.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, Exiled Afghan Insurgent, Nears a Comeback
item.media:description: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar in 1996. Mr. Hekmatyar is working to formally reconcile with the Afghan government for the first time since the end of the country’s civil war.
item.description: The leader of Hezb-i-Islami, known for making and breaking alliances, is trying to work another deal. But some fear he might be more troublesome in Kabul than he is in hiding.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Congo Lurches Toward a New Crisis as Leader Tries to Crush a Rival
item.media:description: Moïse Katumbi in his home in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Monday.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Moïse Katumbi, a popular opposition politician, is the greatest threat to President Joseph Kabila’s rule. He and his supporters are now being targeted by Mr. Kabila’s security services.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Kenya, Citing Terror Threat, Plans to Expel Somali Refugees
item.description: International aid agencies said shutting down the massive Dadaab refugee camp would violate international law and endanger hundreds of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Abortion Rates in Developed Countries Have Fallen Since 1990
item.description: A study in The Lancet showed that worldwide abortion rates were dropping over all, but holding steady in developing countries.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Canada’s Oil Sands Industry Staggers After a Devastating Fire
item.media:description: Smoke filling the street in deserted downtown Fort McMurray in Alberta, Canada, last week. A devastating fire in the region continues to rage.
item.description: Companies either curbed production or shut down completely when the blaze struck Fort McMurray, Alberta, in an economic blow to the region.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: David Cameron Calls Nigeria Corrupt, and Its President Agrees
item.description: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria said through a spokesman that he was “deeply shocked and embarrassed” by Mr. Cameron’s remarks — but he did not rebut them.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: One of Florence’s Oldest Families and Its 600-Year Archive
item.media:description: Prince Filippo and Princess Giorgiana Corsini with the villa’s current occupants, their son Duccio and his wife, Clotilde.
item.media:credit: Photograph by Danilo Scarpati. Produced by Marella Caracciolo Chia.
item.description: The Corsinis kept a record detailing their every decision — and every ledger, bill and correspondence they ever produced.
item.dc:creator: TIM PARKS

item.title: Fontenay-Sous-Bois Journal: In Paris Suburbs, Adopting a Dreaded School Test as a Tool of Integration
item.media:description: Children who participated in a dictation waited to get a free grammar and vocabulary book in Nantes, France, in March. The collective dictations, known as “La Dictée des Cités,” started three years ago.
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.description: Every Saturday in the heavily immigrant suburbs of Paris, people of all ages and social backgrounds gather to do a dictation, a step toward learning “good French.”
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Scores Are Killed as a Wave of Bombings Bloodies Baghdad
item.description: The most deadly attack, at a crowded market in the Sadr City district, was claimed by the Islamic State. Two more bombings were reported at police checkpoints in the capital.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Suicide on Periscope Prompts French Officials to Open Inquiry
item.media:description: The Égly station, about 25 miles south of Paris, on Wednesday. A young woman threw herself under a train at the Égly station while recording herself on Periscope on Tuesday.
item.description: Officials are looking into an episode in which a young woman recorded herself jumping in front of a train outside Paris on the live video-streaming app.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: 10 Nations Move On to Eurovision Final
item.description: The first of two semifinals in the song contest was held Tuesday night in Stockholm. The favorites this year include Russia and Malta.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Rob Schmitz on Shanghai’s ‘Street of Eternal Happiness’
item.media:description: Rob Schmitz’s new book explores the lives of people on his street in Shanghai, including Chen Kai, above, who rose from a difficult boyhood, turned his back on a secure managerial job to start his own business and is now engaged in a quest for deeper meaning.
item.description: When Mr. Schmitz wrote his book on China, he looked to his daily surroundings in Shanghai rather than to some of the more exotic locales where he has reported.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Queen Elizabeth II Says Chinese Officials Were ‘Very Rude’ on State Visit
item.media:description: Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, and President Xi Jinping of China listening as Queen Elizabeth II spoke at a state banquet at Buckingham Palace in London in October 2015.
item.description: A video of a garden party, which has been posted online, included an exchange in which the queen had sharp words for the officials’ behavior last year.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Kerry Rebuts Claims That U.S. Is Undercutting Iran Trade and Investment
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry disputed complaints that American sanctions are impeding business with Iran despite the nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Anne Deborah Atai-Omoruto, Who Helped Lead Ebola Fight in Liberia, Dies at 59
item.media:description: Anne Deborah Atai-Omoruto, who died on May 5, was a doctor instrumental in curbing the 2014 Ebola epidemic in Liberia.
item.description: Dr. Atai-Omoruto trained more than 1,000 Liberian health workers for treating patients with the virus at a time of international panic.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: Romania Takes Step Toward Restitution to Holocaust Survivors
item.description: New legislation on claims for property lost during and after World War II was seen as a small acknowledgment of the treatment of Jews.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Global Warming Cited as Wildfires Increase in Fragile Boreal Forest
item.media:description: Charred trees near Fort McMurray, in Alberta, Canada. Climate change is a prime suspect in a rise of wildfires in the boreal forest.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Scientists say the near-destruction of Fort McMurray last week by a wildfire is the latest indication that the vital boreal forest is at risk from climate change.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS and HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Court Papers Reveal Qaeda Operative’s Work as Trainer and Bomb Expert
item.media:description: Anwar al-Awlaki, an American imam who joined Al Qaeda in Yemen and was later killed in a U.S. drone strike. Court filings in New York offer the most detailed account yet of a hidden side of Mr. Awlaki’s work.
item.description: Anwar al-Awlaki, the U.S. imam who joined Al Qaeda in Yemen and was killed in a 2011 drone strike, was revealed as a trainer who advised recruits on how to make bombs and carry out suicide attacks.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE and BENJAMIN WEISER
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Hollande Bypasses France’s Lower House on Labor Law Overhaul
item.media:description: On Tuesday, demonstrators outside France’s National Assembly, protesting the use of a constitutional article by France’s President Francois Hollande to push through a labor bill. Unemployment has been above 10 percent for years.
item.description: The French president forced through a measure that he says will encourage employers to hire more. Opponents say it weakens worker protections.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte’s Many Sides: Brash and Crude or Tough and Shrewd
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte at a campaign rally in Manila on Saturday. He has said that as president he would aggressively pursue those who break the law.
item.description: As Mr. Duterte appears poised to become the country’s next president, people who know him well say the depiction of him as a crass vigilante is an oversimplification.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: What in the World: The Wrong Day to Be a Cat in Belgium
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photo by Inna Astakhova / shutterstock.com
item.description: The people of Ypres, Belgium, once dealt with feral cats by throwing them off a bell tower. Today, they host a cat-themed celebration instead.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: Look Out, Celebrity Chefs. Here Comes Kim Jong-un.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photo by KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Entities linked to North Korea run an expanding empire of restaurants abroad, pumping badly needed profits back to the North.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: 25 Seconds That Could Save a Firefighter’s Life (or Not)
item.media:description: Government-issue fire shelters.
item.description: A fire shelter is mandatory equipment when fighting a wildfire in the United States, but in Canada, firefighters stopped carrying them in 2005.
item.dc:creator: FERNANDA SANTOS

item.title: What in the World: Rents in London? If You Have to Ask ...
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin, Photo by nok nok/shutterstock.com
item.description: An average apartment in London now costs nine-tenths of an average worker’s pay.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Bangladesh Braces for Violence After Opposition Leader, Motiur Rahman Nizami, Is Executed
item.media:description: A photo of Motiur Rahman Nizami, a senior opposition leader who led Jamaat-e-Islami, Bangladesh’s largest Islamic party, brandished in front of the central jail before his hanging in Dhaka, the capital, early Wednesday morning.
item.description: Motiur Rahman Nizami, leader of the country’s largest Islamic party, was hanged on a 2014 conviction of committing atrocities in the 1971 war of independence.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.S. Has Taken In Less Than a Fifth of Pledged Syrian Refugees
item.media:description: The Sharaf family, refugees from Syria, shopping in November in Troy, Mich. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, has repeatedly called on world leaders to accept refugees, but his pleas have been met with reluctance.
item.media:credit: Salwan Georges for The New York Times
item.description: Seven months after President Obama pledged to accept 10,000 Syrian refugees in a year, the United States has accepted just 1,736.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Rwanda Ex-Mayors Suspected of Roles in Genocide Go on Trial
item.description: Proceedings began in Paris against two former mayors accused of orchestrating and taking part in the mass killing of Tutsi refugees and moderate Hutu in 1994.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Israel Defense Forces vs. the People of Israel
item.media:description: Israelis observing Memorial Day at a military cemetery in Jerusalem.
item.description: Once embraced by Jewish Israelis of all stripes, the army has become estranged from much of the public.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The New Strongman of Manila
item.description: I asked a police officer, “Should I be scared?”
item.dc:creator: LAUREL FANTAUZZO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Miserable French Workplace
item.media:description: People opposed to the French government’s labor reform law protested in Paris on Tuesday.
item.description: Why is it so hard to change the labor laws?
item.dc:creator: PAMELA DRUCKERMAN

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
